name: Soy Shawarma
name_origin: The term 'Shawarma' (שווארמה) is an Arabized corruption of the Ottoman Turkish word 'çevirme' (pronounced che-vir-meh), which means 'turning' or 'rotating,' referring to the vertical rotisserie cooking method. The suffix 'Soya' (סויה) is a Modern Hebrew loanword (ultimately from Japanese 'shoyu' via Dutch/English) indicating the vegetarian protein base. While the dish appears in a Djerban context here, the name and concept are Modern Israeli adaptations of Levantine street food, not traditional North African Jewish cuisine.
description: A vegetarian adaptation of the classic street food using textured soy protein. The soy strips are first rehydrated in a deeply spiced vegetable broth to absorb flavor, then pan-seared with onions and finished with tangy amba sauce.
cultural_context: While traditional Shawarma is meat-based, this recipe reflects modern Israeli and Jewish adaptations using traditional spice blends like Ras el Hanout and Amba (pickled mango sauce) to maintain authentic flavor profiles in a pareve/vegan dish.

ingredients.name: Dried soy strips (TVP)
ingredients.notes: Textured Vegetable Protein strips or curls

steps.instruction: Bring the vegetable stock to a boil in a large pot.
steps.tips: If you don't have fresh stock, water with vegetable bouillon powder works well.

steps.instruction: Add the dried soy strips to the boiling stock along with the first batch of spices: half the shawarma spice, salt, white pepper, garlic powder, and half the Ras el Hanout.
Cook the strips in the spiced broth for about 20 minutes until fully rehydrated and tender. Drain well.
steps.tips: Squeeze out excess liquid from the strips after draining for better texture when frying.

steps.instruction: Heat the oil in a frying pan or skillet. Add the sliced onion and fry until golden.
Add the drained soy strips to the pan. Fry until they begin to brown and crisp slightly.
Season the frying mixture with the remaining shawarma spice, cumin, and the rest of the Ras el Hanout.
Just before removing from heat, stir in the Amba sauce for a tangy finish.
steps.tips: Amba is potent; add gradually to taste.

name_etymology.notes: Standard culinary etymology. The Turkish 'çevirme' became the Arabic 'shawarma' (changing the 'ch' to 'sh'). It is important to note that this is a modern 'pareve' (neutral) adaptation, likely created to allow the consumption of a shawarma-style dish within a dairy meal or for vegetarians, rather than a historical Djerban dish.

alternative_names.name: Chawarma Végétarienne
alternative_names.notes: Common nomenclature in modern Tunisia and France

similar_dishes.name: Döner Kebab
similar_dishes.similarity: The original meat-based dish cooked on a vertical rotisserie.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Made with lamb or beef; the 'soy' version is pan-seared rather than roasted on a spit.

similar_dishes.name: Gyros
similar_dishes.similarity: Vertical rotisserie meat dish derived from the same Ottoman tradition.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Often made with pork or chicken and served with tzatziki (yogurt), which is forbidden in kosher meat meals (though permissible with this soy version).

similar_dishes.name: Shawarma
similar_dishes.similarity: The meat-based street food this dish emulates.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses layers of fat and meat (lamb, turkey, chicken) rather than textured vegetable protein.

intro_paragraph: Soy Shawarma takes its name from the Turkish *çevirme*, meaning "turning," but replaces rotisserie meat with textured soy protein for a modern twist. Rehydrated in spiced broth and pan-seared with onions, the strips are finished with tangy amba. This pareve dish uses traditional seasoning to capture the savory essence of street food without the meat.
